string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.

slidelink.displaytext: Calculate the Volume of a Cylindrical Pool

search.slidetext: welcome to pool volume how to calculate the volume of a cylindrical pool begin begin begin begin begin

you have now completed all lessons and learnt how to find the volume of a cylindrical pool. click below to exit the course. exit course exit course exit course exit course exit course how to calculate the volume of a pool lesson two why the volume of a pool is important lesson one what you will learn begin begin begin begin begin how to calculate the volume of a pool lesson two what you will learn begin begin begin begin begin why the volume of a pool is important lesson one

pool volume is necessary for calculating water circulation rates and maintaining water quality. accurate volume measurements also aid in heating and filtration system sizing. it helps determine the amount of water the pool can hold, which is essential for maintenance and chemical treatment. the volume of a pool is crucial for several reasons. click each button below to find out why. volume of a pool water water water water water water water heat heat heat heat heat heat heat quality quality quality quality quality quality quality click to learn more https://www.swimmingpool.com/resources/ lesson 1 > why the volume of a pool is important

incorrect knowing the volume of the pool will not affect the pool aesthetics. try again. return return return return return incorrect you dont need to know the volume to be able to calculate the temperature of the water. try again. return return return return return correct it is important to find the volume of the pool to determine the amount of water the pool can hold. continue continue continue continue continue to calculate the water temperature. to calculate the water temperature. to calculate the water temperature. to calculate the water temperature. to calculate the water temperature. to calculate the water temperature. for pool aesthetics. for pool aesthetics. for pool aesthetics. for pool aesthetics. for pool aesthetics. for pool aesthetics. to determine the amount of water the pool can hold. to determine the amount of water the pool can hold. to determine the amount of water the pool can hold. to determine the amount of water the pool can hold. to determine the amount of water the pool can hold. to determine the amount of water the pool can hold. select the correct response. why is it important to know the volume of a pool? lesson 1 > why the volume of a pool is important
to calculate a pool's volume, you'll need to know the shape of the pool. let's consider a cylindrical pool for this example. lesson 2 > how to calculate the volume of a pool
the equation to find the volume of a cylindrical pool, we use the formula for the volume of a cylinder: volume = rh remember: = 3.14159 lesson 2 > how to calculate the volume of a pool

example 1 residential pool the pool has a radius of 1.52 metres and a height of 1.22 metres. using the equation lets find the volume. volume = rh volume = 3.14159 x (1.52)2 x 1.22 volume = 8.86 cubic metres lesson 2 > how to calculate the volume of a pool try it for yourself. use your calculator to complete the equation. did you get the same result?

14.22m3 0.76 5.9536 3.14159 example 2: community pool volume volume r r h h the pool has a diameter of 4.88 metres and a depth of 0.76 metres. note: sometimes you will receive measurements in diameters and depth. depth is the same as height, but diameter needs to be divided by 2 to find the radius. hover over each card below to see the equation in play. lesson 2 > how to calculate the volume of a pool try it for yourself. did you get the same result?

to find the volume of a cylindrical pool, we use the formula for the volume of a cylinder: volume = rh correct! lesson 2 > how to calculate the volume of a pool r2 r2 r2 r2 volume volume volume volume h h h h drag and drop the words to complete the equation. drag and drop the words to complete the equation. drag and drop the words to complete the equation. lesson 2 > how to calculate the volume of a pool

incorrect remember, the equation is volume = rh. in this example, v = 3.14159 x (5.94)2 x 3.2. try again. return return return return return correct the volume of the pool is 354.71m3. continue continue continue continue continue 59.72m3 59.72m3 59.72m3 59.72m3 59.72m3 59.72m3 112.91m3 112.91m3 112.91m3 112.91m3 112.91m3 112.91m3 354.71m3 354.71m3 354.71m3 354.71m3 354.71m3 354.71m3 1,135.07m3 1,135.07m3 1,135.07m3 1,135.07m3 1,135.07m3 1,135.07m3 119.43m3 119.43m3 119.43m3 119.43m3 119.43m3 119.43m3 whats the volume? you are measuring the volume of a cylindrical school swimming pool. the radius is 5.94m and the depth is 3.2m. what is the volume of the pool? lesson 2 > how to calculate the volume of a pool

incorrect remember, the equation is volume = rh. dont forget to change the diameter to radius. in this example, v = 3.14159 x (3.05)2 x 3.66. try again. return return return return return correct the volume of the pool is 106.96m3. continue continue continue continue continue test yourself find the volume of a hotel resort pool. the dimensions are: diameter: 6.10m depth: 3.66m lesson 2 > how to calculate the volume of a pool submit submit submit submit submit type here m3

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Update the slide with the Course Code and Course Name
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Update the slide name with the Course Code" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Update chapter names
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Replace icons with suitable icons based on chapter name
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Update triggers and variables (update as required)
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Note: Variables are to follow the naming convention of Ch#Completed
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="More than 4 chapters?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Consider removing the icons and designing tiles, or
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Create each chapter on a new line
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Add additional variables and triggers as required
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Less than 4 chapters?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Remove triggers and variables that are not required
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Update/Enable the triggers on each layer to navigate to/return to the correct slide. E.g. Jump to Scene Chapter 2 when student clicks on Begin on Chapter 2 layer. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Use this for important content or an introduction
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Ensure each paragraph appears after the next in the timeline
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Ensure title with paragraphs are vertically aligned" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Sometimes a better use than buttons when there is small text. Add more flip cards as necessary. Update the layers appropriately." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Useful as an alternative to a two button slide. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Each paragraph is shown separately so there is not too much on the page. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Note that there are two square boxes to the right, these are considered the wrong drop box. This is so that there are always two options at the top of the page. You will see that there are 4 drag and drops (2 for the first sentence and 2 for the second). When you preview this slide you will see it in action.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="

Get the student to stop for a second and think." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
